2025 Paper 1 Non-calculator. 55 marks. 1 hour 15 minutes. Question 1 (4 marks) Hint 1 To find the equation of a line you will need to find its gradient. How can you find the gradient of a tangent to a curve? Hint 2 Differentiate and substitute in \(x=\) to find the gradient of the tangent. Next you just need to know a point the tangent passes through. How can you find the \(y\)-coordinate which corresponds to \(x=2\)? Hint 3 Substitute \(x=2\) into \(y=x^3-2x^2+5\) to find the corresponding \(y\)-coordinate. Use that coordinate together with the gradient found and the straight line equation \(y-b=m(x-a)\). Answer \(y=4x-3\) Solution Question 2 (4 marks) Hint 1 What are the properties of a perpendicular bisector? Hint 2 Start by finding the gradient of line AB. What then is the gradient of its perpendicular bisector? Hint 3 Once you have the gradient perpendicular to line AB, find the midpoint of AB. This coordinate and the perpendicular gradient can be used with \(y-b=m(x-a)\). Answer \(3y=-4x+41\) or \(y=-\dfrac{4}{3}x+\dfrac{41}{3}\) Solution Question 3 (4 marks) Hint 1 One of the terms is not yet ready to be integrated. Which one? How can it be rewritten? Hint 2 \(\dfrac{12}{x^2}\) can be written as \(12x^{-2}\). The rule for integrating is increase the power by one then divide by the new power. What should the answer to an indefinite integration include? Hint 3 Dividing by \(\dfrac{3}{2}\) is the same as multiplying by \(\dfrac{2}{3}\). Remember to simplify each part as much as possible and include "\(+\mathrm{C}\)". Answer \(-12x^{-1}+\dfrac{2}{3}x^{\frac{3}{2}}+\mathrm{C}\) Solution Question 4 (3 marks) Hint 1 What are the three log laws? Which must be applied first here? Hint 2 Use the power law \(y\log_ax=\log_ax^y\) to remove the \(2\) from the front of the first log. Next, what happens when to logs are added? Hint 3 Remember that \(3^{-1}=\dfrac{1}{3}\). What therefore is the value of \(\log_3{\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)}\)? Answer \(-1\) Solution Question 5 (2 marks) Hint 1 This is a graph transformations question. What does the transformation \(f(-x)\dots\) do? What does the transformation \(f(\dots)+3\) do? Hint 2 Write down the three coordinates given on the graph of \(y=f(x)\). \(f(-x)\dots\) "flips" the \(x\)-coordinates. \(f(\dots)+3\) adds \(3\) to the \(y\)-coordinates. Write down the three transformed coordinates. Hint 3 The three coordinates are \((-4,3\), \((0,6)\) and \((2,3)\). Use them to sketch a graph which is "flipped horizontally" and shifted up \(3\). Answer Solution Question 6 (4 marks) Hint 1 The diagram shows angle \(q\) but the questions ask about \(2Q\). How can \(\sin{2q}\) and \(\cos{2q}\) be expanded? The length of the right-angled triangle's hypotenuse will be needed in this question. Hint 2 Use \(\sin{2q}=2\sin{q}\cos{q}\) and \(\cos{2q}=2\cos^2{q}-1\). The length of the hypotenuse is \(\sqrt{5^2+1^2}\). From the triangle, write down the values of \(\sin{q}\) and \(\cos{q}\). Hint 3 Substitute the values of \(\sin{q}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{26}}\) and \(\cos{q}=\dfrac{5}{\sqrt{26}}\). Then simplify. Answer \(\sin{2q}=\dfrac{5}{13}\) and \(\cos{2q}=\dfrac{12}{13}\) Solution (3 marks) Hint 1 How can \(\sin{(2q-r)}\) be expanded? Hint 2 Use \(\sin{(2q-r)}=\sin{2q}\cos{r}-\cos{2q}\sin{r}\). The values of \(\sin{2q}\) and \(\cos{2q}\) have already been found in part (a). What are the values of \(\sin{r}\) and \(\cos{r}\)? Hint 3 Substitute \(\sin{r}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{17}}\) and \(\cos{r}=\dfrac{4}{\sqrt{17}}\) into the expanded form. Answer \(\dfrac{8}{13\sqrt{17}}\) Solution Question 7 (5 marks) Hint 1 Hint 1.
